description: From French banneret, from bannière (“banner”) + -et (“-et, -ette: forming diminutives”). Equivalent to banner +‎ -et.

entries.meaning: (law, historical) Clipping of knight banneret: a knight entitled to subinfeudate his estate and to lead men in battle under his own banner.

examples: His armor and his horse were black; there was no device on his shield and no banneret on his spear.

entries.meaning: (military, historical) A proposed but unadopted senior commissioned rank of the Royal Air Force equivalent to group captain.
examples: A list of new titles was manufactured as follows: Ensign, Lieutenant, Flight-Leader, Squadron-Leader, Reeve, Banneret, Fourth-Ardian, Third-Ardian, Second-Ardian, Ardian, Air Marshal. […O]ne may regret “Banneret”, which has a flavour and associations, more especially as the leader of a formation in the air went into battle flying a streamer which formed a rallying mark as did the banner of the knight for his vassals.

entries.meaning: A civil officer in some Swiss cantons.
